deIdi2b2.TEXT:
Record date: 2065-12-19 EDVISIT^60244986^XIAN, BROOKLYN^12/19/65^QUAGLIA, BRONSON
I confirm that I have interviewed and examined the patient and
reviewed the PA's documentation. Please see her note for full
details.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Ms. Xian is a 70-year-old female
with a history of non-insulin-dependent diabetes, history of
cholecystectomy, and Lap-Band in 2062 who presents with right
upper quadrant abdominal pain, nausea but no vomiting, and
decreased p.o. intake. Denies any fevers. She reports that it
is 8/10 and 12/10 at its worst. She also on review of systems
reports some chest pain on the left side radiating down her left
arm and left shoulder. No previous episodes. No trauma, no
urinary symptoms, no vomiting, and no diarrhea. She saw her PCP
earlier this week on 12/17/2065 and had a CT scan, which was
reportedly normal and it is in our system and we have confirmed
this reading.
SOCIAL HISTORY: Noncontributory.
FAMILY HISTORY: Normal.
REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: Otherwise, negative. LMR notes on 12/17/2065
from her PCP reveals same steady mild waxing and waning right
upper quadrant abdominal pain radiating to the back, not
pleuritic. No shortness of breath. No fevers, cough, or chills.
No changes in her stools.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: She has a history of sleep apnea, atypical
chest pain, diabetes, obesity, gastric banding, and some
dementia.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Here, heart rate 76, respiratory rate 18,
blood pressure 118/77, saturations 97%, and temperature 96.6.
She is obese. Dry Mucous membranes. Slightly pale. Neck is
supple. No respiratory distress. Normal breath sounds. Heart:
Regular rate and rhythm without a murmur. Abdomen with right
upper quadrant tenderness. Negative Murphy's. No
hepatosplenomegaly and no CVA tenderness.
IMPRESSION: This 70-year-old female with abdominal pain.
LABORATORY DATA: White count of 15.6, hematocrit 42. The rest
of her labs are pending. Chest x-ray and right upper quadrant
ultrasound pending. Otherwise, we have given IV fluids and
morphine. She is on telemetry.
Diagnoses at this time, abdominal pain and chest pain. Abdominal
pain. With a negative CT scan, labs and ultrasound that are
reassuring. We will proceed with pain control at that time.
Chest pain. We will ____ check a troponin and EKG and keep her
in telemetry. She will get ____ and if there has been a negative
recent nuclear stress test, we will go ahead and proceed with ED
Observation admission in the morning for a MIBI stress test.
DIAGNOSES:
1. Abdominal pain.
2. Chest pain.
______________________________
QUAGLIA, BRONSON M.D.
D: 12/19/65
T: 12/19/65
Dictated By: QUAGLIA, BRONSON
